comment_text.dn8:1.2: Ujuññā was a Kosalan town at which King Pasenadi visited the Buddha in MN 90. | “Deer parks” were nature reservations where the animals were safe from hunters.
comment_text.dn8:1.3: Naked ascetics are still found in India today. Some Jains went naked, but if he were a Jain he would have been introduced as such. Kassapa is an ancient clan name of the brahmins, and we meet four naked ascetics named Kassapa in the canon (here, SN 12.17, SN 41.9, and MN 124). They cannot be the same person, for at the end of each account it is said they went forth and attained arahantship.
comment_text.dn8:2.2: In his first sermon, the Buddha rejected extremes of self-mortification. There the term was attakilamatha (“self-mortification”), whereas here it is tapas (“heat, burning, fervor”). These refer to the same practices, but tapas points to the fervent ardor of the practitioner, generating an inner heat that “burns off” the corrupting traces of kamma and defilements. This topic is also discussed in AN 10.94.
comment_text.dn8:3.3: While the self-mortification itself may be useless, the person who practices it may have other good qualities. The Buddha is cautioning against rash judgement.
comment_text.dn8:5.2: Again we see the Buddha’s preferred method of establishing common ground first, then building an argument from there.
comment_text.dn8:5.5: Rather than logical hair-splitting, the Buddha recommends looking at a person’s conduct.
comment_text.dn8:13.2: Here -va has an exclusive sense (= eva). Compare Dhp 274: eseva maggo natthañño (“This is the path, there is no other”).
comment_text.dn8:14.2: What follows is a description of ascetic practices undertaken by the Jains and similar groups. | The phrase “course of fervent mortification” (tapopakkama) is unique to this sutta. Pakkama means “stepping out”.
comment_text.dn8:14.3: Buddhist mendicants may not receive food in their hands, nor lick them while eating. Followers of the practices listed here would have walked steadily and randomly for alms, accepting only what was given at the time.
comment_text.dn8:14.4: Keeping sheep (eḷaka, for slaughter) goes against the Jain principle of non-violence, as does keeping weapons (daṇḍa). | A musala often means “pestle”, but it can also be a “shovel”; at MN 81:18.12 it is regarded as a virtue to not use one to dig the soil (which is regarded as being alive in Jainism). | Thusodaka is an alcoholic porridge fermented from grain-husks, mentioned alongside sovīraka in the Pali commentaries and Carakasaṁhitā 27g.191.
comment_text.dn8:14.9: It is not easy to meaningfully distinguish the various kinds of grain.
comment_text.dn8:14.11: All are extremely uncomfortable. Christian ascetics wore a “hair shirt” in order to “mortify the flesh” .
comment_text.dn8:14.12: Jain ascetics tear out their hair at ordination, rather than shaving.
comment_text.dn8:14.13: Remaining in one posture for months or years at a time is one of the most difficult practices.
comment_text.dn8:14.18: Strict Jain ascetics did not bathe.
comment_text.dn8:14.21: At Kd 6:14.6.3 the four “great unnaturals” (or “filthy edibles”, mahāvikaṭa) are said to be feces, urine, ash, and clay. At MN 12:49.3 the Buddha said he ate the “unnatural things” of feces and urine when undertaking ascetic practices.
comment_text.dn8:14.23: This seems out of place here. It was a Brahmanical practice (SN 7.21), as the Jains refused to bathe at all. Indeed, bathing three times a day in the Indian climate would, for most of the year, be quite pleasant.
comment_text.dn8:15.2: The term “accomplishment in mind” (cittasampadā) is equivalent to “accomplishment in immersion” (samādhisampadā). More generally, when citta is used in the context of meditation, it is normally a synonym of samādhi.
comment_text.dn8:15.3: Mettā is universal love and good will free from attachment. As well as being a foundation for good character and healthy emotional development, it serves to lead the mind into deep meditation of jhāna.
comment_text.dn8:16.11: The Buddha was criticized for going soft after abandoning austere practices, but here he flips the script, arguing that it is inner transformation that is really hard, not outer shows of mortification.
comment_text.dn8:18.2: Note that the heading for this section in the Mahāsaṅgīti edition uses samādhi rather than citta. Headings were added by later editors, and are not part of the original text.
comment_text.dn8:21.4: This is the ethical practices as described in the Gradual Training.
comment_text.dn8:21.5: “Mortification in disgust of sin” renders tapojigucchā; tapo is “fervent mortification” and jigucchā is “loathing, disgust”. It captures the severity with which practitioners regarded the “evil” or “sin” with which they were infected, like a quasi-physical stain on the soul, and the burning flame of white-hot pain required to cauterize their spiritual wounds.
comment_text.dn8:21.8: The Buddha repurposes the concept of “disgust of sin”, which here stands in the place of meditation (samādhi).
comment_text.dn8:22.2: A “lion’s roar” is an unapologetic proclamation of spiritual supremacy.
comment_text.dn8:23.2: The Buddha is referring to the events of the Udumbarikasutta (DN 25). There Nigrodha is referred to as a “wanderer” (paribbājaka) who according to the commentary was clothed. The term tapabrahmacārī here is unique and is not explained in the commentary. I think it means he was a celibate student of a Brahmanical teacher. Tapas and brahmacariya are closely linked in Atharvaveda 11.5.
comment_text.dn8:23.10: In the early period, there was no distinction between “going forth” (pabbajjā) and “ordination” (upasampadā). They refer to two sides of the same coin: leaving the home life and entering the ascetic life. Ordination was originally granted by the Buddha with the simple call, “Come mendicant!” (Kd 1:6.32.1). As the community grew, the Buddha authorized the Saṅgha to perform the “going forth and ordination” (Kd 1:12.1.1). Later still, the novice (sāmaṇera) platform was introduced for teenagers and became known as “going forth” (Kd 1:54.3.2). Finally, the novice ordination was standardized for all ordinands, even if it was a mere preliminary for the “full ordination”.
comment_text.dn8:24.1: This probation is laid down in the Vinaya at Kd 1:38.1.5. The candidate shaves, dons the robes, takes refuge, and asks for probation. They must show good conduct and restraint, diligence in duties, and enthusiasm for the Buddha’s teachings and practice.
comment_text.dn8:24.2: In addition to individual exceptions, there are general exceptions for dreadlocked fire-worshipping ascetics, since they believe in kamma, and for the Buddha’s relatives (Kd 1:38.11.3).

root_text.dn8:22.1: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, kassapa, vijjati, yaṁ aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṁ vadeyyuṁ:
root_text.dn8:22.2: ‘sīhanādaṁ kho samaṇo gotamo nadati, tañca kho suññāgāre nadati, no parisāsū’ti.
root_text.dn8:22.4: ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadatī’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā.

root_text.dn8:22.13: pañhassa ca veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheti; no ca kho sotabbaṁ maññanti …pe…

root_text.dn8:22.16: pasannākārañca karonti; no ca kho tathattāya paṭipajjanti …pe…
root_text.dn8:22.17: tathattāya ca paṭipajjanti; no ca kho paṭipannā ārādhentī’ti.
root_text.dn8:22.19: ‘Sīhanādañca samaṇo gotamo nadati, parisāsu ca nadati, visārado ca nadati, pañhañca naṁ pucchanti, pañhañca nesaṁ puṭṭho byākaroti, pañhassa ca veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheti, sotabbañcassa maññanti, sutvā cassa pasīdanti, pasannākārañca karonti, tathattāya ca paṭipajjanti, paṭipannā ca ārādhentī’ti evamassu, kassapa, vacanīyā.
root_text.dn8:23.1: Ekamidāhaṁ, kassapa, samayaṁ rājagahe viharāmi gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
root_text.dn8:23.2: Tatra maṁ aññataro tapabrahmacārī nigrodho nāma adhijegucche pañhaṁ apucchi.
root_text.dn8:23.4: Byākate ca pana me attamano ahosi paraṁ viya mattāyā”ti.
root_text.dn8:23.5: “Ko hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṁ sutvā na attamano assa paraṁ viya mattāya?
root_text.dn8:23.6: Ahampi hi, bhante, bhagavato dhammaṁ sutvā attamano paraṁ viya mattāya.
root_text.dn8:23.8: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.dn8:23.9: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi, dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.dn8:23.10: Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
root_text.dn8:24.1: “Yo kho, kassapa, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṁ, so cattāro māse parivasati, catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya.
root_text.dn8:24.3: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhanti pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhanti upasampadaṁ, cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya. Ahaṁ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi, catunnaṁ vassānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu, upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
root_text.dn8:24.4: Alattha kho acelo kassapo bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.
root_text.dn8:24.5: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā kassapo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto na cirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.dn8:24.6: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.dn8:24.7: Aññataro kho panāyasmā kassapo arahataṁ ahosīti.

translation_text.dn8:0.2: The Lion’s Roar to the Naked Ascetic Kassapa
translation_text.dn8:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ujuññā, in the deer park at Kaṇṇakatthala.
translation_text.dn8:1.3: Then the naked ascetic Kassapa went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn8:1.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.dn8:2.1: “Worthy Gotama, I have heard the following:
translation_text.dn8:2.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama criticizes all fervent mortification. He categorically condemns and denounces all fervent mortifiers who live rough.’
translation_text.dn8:2.3: Do those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?
translation_text.dn8:2.4: For we don’t want to misrepresent the worthy Gotama.”
translation_text.dn8:3.1: “Kassapa, those who say this do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false, baseless, and untrue.
translation_text.dn8:3.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see some fervent mortifier who lives rough reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.dn8:3.3: But I see another fervent mortifier who lives rough reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn8:3.4: I see some fervent mortifier who takes it easy reborn in a place of loss.
translation_text.dn8:3.5: But I see another fervent mortifier who takes it easy reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.dn8:3.6: Since I truly understand the coming and going, passing away and rebirth of these fervent mortifiers in this way, how could I criticize all forms of mortification, or categorically condemn and denounce those fervent mortifiers who live rough?
translation_text.dn8:4.1: There are some clever ascetics and brahmins who are subtle, accomplished in the doctrines of others, hair-splitters. You’d think they live to demolish convictions with their intellect.
translation_text.dn8:4.2: They agree with me in some matters and disagree in others.
translation_text.dn8:4.3: Some of the things that they applaud, I also applaud.
translation_text.dn8:4.4: Some of the things that they don’t applaud, I also don’t applaud.
translation_text.dn8:4.5: But some of the things that they applaud, I don’t applaud.
translation_text.dn8:4.6: And some of the things that they don’t applaud, I do applaud.
translation_text.dn8:4.7: Some of the things that I applaud, others also applaud.
translation_text.dn8:4.8: Some of the things that I don’t applaud, they also don’t applaud.
translation_text.dn8:4.9: But some of the things that I don’t applaud, others do applaud.
translation_text.dn8:4.10: And some of the things that I do applaud, others don’t applaud.
translation_text.dn8:5.1: I go up to them and say:
translation_text.dn8:5.2: ‘Let us leave aside those matters on which we disagree.
translation_text.dn8:5.3: But there are some matters on which we agree. Regarding these, sensible people, pursuing, pressing, and grilling, would compare teacher with teacher or community with community:
translation_text.dn8:5.4: “There are things that are unskillful, blameworthy, not to be cultivated, unworthy of the noble ones, and dark—and are reckoned as such.
translation_text.dn8:5.5: Who proceeds having totally given these things up: the ascetic Gotama, or the tutors of other communities?”’
translation_text.dn8:6.1: It’s possible that they might say:
translation_text.dn8:6.3: ‘The ascetic Gotama proceeds having totally given those unskillful things up, compared with the tutors of other communities.’
translation_text.dn8:6.4: And that’s how, when sensible people pursue the matter, they will mostly praise us.
translation_text.dn8:7.1: In addition, sensible people, pursuing, pressing, and grilling, would compare teacher with teacher or community with community:
translation_text.dn8:7.2: ‘There are things that are skillful, blameless, worth cultivating, worthy of the noble ones, and bright—and are reckoned as such.
translation_text.dn8:7.3: Who proceeds having totally undertaken these things: the ascetic Gotama, or the tutors of other communities?’
translation_text.dn8:8.1: It’s possible that they might say:
translation_text.dn8:8.3: ‘The ascetic Gotama proceeds having totally undertaken these things, compared with the tutors of other communities.’
translation_text.dn8:8.4: And that’s how, when sensible people pursue the matter, they will mostly praise us.

translation_text.dn8:10.4: And that’s how, when sensible people pursue the matter, they will mostly praise us.

translation_text.dn8:13.1: There is, Kassapa, a path, there is a practice, practicing in accordance with which you will know and see for yourself:
translation_text.dn8:13.2: ‘Only the ascetic Gotama’s words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.’
translation_text.dn8:13.5: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.dn8:13.6: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.dn8:13.7: This is the path, this is the practice, practicing in accordance with which you will know and see for yourself: ‘Only the ascetic Gotama’s words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training.’”
translation_text.dn8:14.1: When he had spoken, Kassapa said to the Buddha:
translation_text.dn8:14.2: “Reverend Gotama, those ascetics and brahmins consider these courses of fervent mortification to be what makes someone a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:14.3: They go naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
translation_text.dn8:14.4: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
translation_text.dn8:14.5: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
translation_text.dn8:14.6: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
translation_text.dn8:14.7: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
translation_text.dn8:14.8: Those ascetics and brahmins also consider these courses of fervent mortification to be what makes someone a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:14.9: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
translation_text.dn8:14.10: Those ascetics and brahmins also consider these courses of fervent mortification to be what makes someone a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:14.11: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
translation_text.dn8:14.12: They tear out hair and beard, committed to this practice.
translation_text.dn8:14.13: They constantly stand, turning down seats.
translation_text.dn8:14.14: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
translation_text.dn8:14.15: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
translation_text.dn8:14.16: They make their bed on a plank, or the bare ground.
translation_text.dn8:14.17: They lie only on one side.
translation_text.dn8:14.19: They stay in the open air.
translation_text.dn8:14.20: They sleep wherever they lay their mat.
translation_text.dn8:14.21: They eat unnatural things, committed to the practice of eating unnatural foods.
translation_text.dn8:14.22: They don’t drink, committed to the practice of not drinking liquids.
translation_text.dn8:14.23: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.”
translation_text.dn8:15.1: “Kassapa, someone may practice all those forms of mortification,
translation_text.dn8:15.2: but if they haven’t developed and realized any accomplishment in ethics, mind, and wisdom, they are far from being a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:15.3: But take a mendicant who develops a heart of love, free of enmity and ill will. And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn8:15.4: When they achieve this, they’re a mendicant who is called a ‘true ascetic’ and also ‘a true brahmin’. …”
translation_text.dn8:16.1: When he had spoken, Kassapa said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn8:16.2: “It’s hard, worthy Gotama, to be a true ascetic or a true brahmin.”
translation_text.dn8:16.3: “It’s typical, Kassapa, in this world to think that it’s hard to be a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:16.4: But someone might practice all those forms of mortification.
translation_text.dn8:16.5: And if it was only because of just that much, only because of that course of fervent mortification that it was so very hard to be a true ascetic or brahmin, it wouldn’t be appropriate to say that
translation_text.dn8:16.6: it’s hard to be a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:16.7: For it would be quite possible for a householder or a householder’s child—or even the bonded maid who carries the water-jar—
translation_text.dn8:16.8: to practice all those forms of mortification.
translation_text.dn8:16.9: It’s because there’s something other than just that much, something other than that course of fervent mortification that it’s so very hard to be a true ascetic or brahmin. And that’s why it is appropriate to say that
translation_text.dn8:16.10: it’s hard to be a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:16.11: Take a mendicant who develops a heart of love, free of enmity and ill will. And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn8:16.12: When they achieve this, they’re a mendicant who is called a ‘true ascetic’ and also ‘a true brahmin’. …”
translation_text.dn8:17.1: When he had spoken, Kassapa said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn8:17.2: “It’s hard, worthy Gotama, to know a true ascetic or a true brahmin.”
translation_text.dn8:17.3: “It’s typical in this world to think that it’s hard to know a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:17.4: But someone might practice all those forms of mortification.
translation_text.dn8:17.5: And if it was only by just that much, only by that  course of fervent mortification that it was so very hard to know a true ascetic or brahmin, it wouldn’t be appropriate to say that
translation_text.dn8:17.6: it’s hard to know a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:17.7: For it would be quite possible for a householder or a householder’s child—or even the bonded maid who carries the water-jar—
translation_text.dn8:17.8: to know that someone is practicing all those forms of mortification.
translation_text.dn8:17.9: It’s because there’s something other than just that much, something other than that course of fervent mortification that it’s so very hard to know a true ascetic or brahmin. And that’s why it is appropriate to say that
translation_text.dn8:17.10: it’s hard to know a true ascetic or brahmin.
translation_text.dn8:17.11: Take a mendicant who develops a heart of love, free of enmity and ill will. And they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn8:17.12: When they achieve this, they’re a mendicant who is called a ‘true ascetic’ and also ‘a true brahmin’.”
translation_text.dn8:18.0: 5. The Accomplishment of Ethics, Mind, and Wisdom
translation_text.dn8:18.1: When he had spoken, Kassapa said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn8:18.2: “But worthy Gotama, what is that accomplishment in ethics, in mind, and in wisdom?”
translation_text.dn8:18.3: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …
translation_text.dn8:18.4: Seeing danger in the slightest fault, a mendicant keeps the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.
translation_text.dn8:18.5: And how is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?
translation_text.dn8:18.6: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.dn8:18.7: This pertains to their accomplishment in ethics. …
translation_text.dn8:19.1: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still earn a living by low lore, by wrong livelihood. …
translation_text.dn8:19.3: They refrain from such low lore, such wrong livelihood.
translation_text.dn8:19.4: This pertains to their accomplishment in ethics.
translation_text.dn8:19.5: A mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
translation_text.dn8:19.6: It’s like a king who has defeated his enemies. He sees no danger from his foes in any quarter.
translation_text.dn8:19.7: In the same way, a mendicant thus accomplished in ethics sees no danger in any quarter in regards to their ethical restraint.
translation_text.dn8:19.8: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
translation_text.dn8:19.9: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics.
translation_text.dn8:19.10: This, Kassapa, is that accomplishment in ethics. …
translation_text.dn8:19.11: They enter and remain in the first absorption …
translation_text.dn8:19.12: This pertains to their accomplishment in mind. …
translation_text.dn8:19.13: They enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.dn8:19.16: This pertains to their accomplishment in mind.
translation_text.dn8:19.17: This, Kassapa, is that accomplishment in mind.
translation_text.dn8:20.1: When their mind is immersed like this,
translation_text.dn8:20.2: they project it and extend it toward knowledge and vision …
translation_text.dn8:20.3: This pertains to their accomplishment in wisdom. …
translation_text.dn8:20.4: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.dn8:20.5: This pertains to their accomplishment in wisdom.
translation_text.dn8:20.6: This, Kassapa, is that accomplishment in wisdom.
translation_text.dn8:20.7: And, Kassapa, there is no accomplishment in ethics, mind, and wisdom that is better or finer than this.
translation_text.dn8:21.1: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach ethics.
translation_text.dn8:21.2: They praise ethical conduct in many ways.
translation_text.dn8:21.3: But as far as the highest noble ethics goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.
translation_text.dn8:21.4: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher ethics.
translation_text.dn8:21.5: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach mortification in disgust of sin.
translation_text.dn8:21.6: They praise fervent mortification in disgust of sin in many ways.
translation_text.dn8:21.7: But as far as the highest noble fervent mortification in disgust of sin goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.
translation_text.dn8:21.8: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher disgust of sin.
translation_text.dn8:21.9: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach wisdom.
translation_text.dn8:21.10: They praise wisdom in many ways.
translation_text.dn8:21.11: But as far as the highest noble wisdom goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.
translation_text.dn8:21.12: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher wisdom.
translation_text.dn8:21.13: There are, Kassapa, some ascetics and brahmins who teach freedom.
translation_text.dn8:21.14: They praise freedom in many ways.
translation_text.dn8:21.15: But as far as the highest noble freedom goes, I don’t see anyone who’s my equal, still less my superior.
translation_text.dn8:21.16: Rather, I am the one who is superior when it comes to the higher freedom.
translation_text.dn8:22.1: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:
translation_text.dn8:22.2: ‘The ascetic Gotama only roars his lion’s roar in an empty hut, not in an assembly.’
translation_text.dn8:22.4: What should be said is this: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, and he roars it in the assemblies.’
translation_text.dn8:22.5: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:
translation_text.dn8:22.6: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, and he roars it in the assemblies. But he doesn’t roar it boldly.’
translation_text.dn8:22.8: What should be said is this: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, he roars it in the assemblies, and he roars it boldly.’
translation_text.dn8:22.9: It’s possible that wanderers of other religions might say:
translation_text.dn8:22.10: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar, he roars it in the assemblies, and he roars it boldly. But they don’t question him. …
translation_text.dn8:22.11: Or he doesn’t answer their questions. …
translation_text.dn8:22.12: Or his answers are not satisfactory. …
translation_text.dn8:22.13: Or they don’t think him worth listening to. …
translation_text.dn8:22.14: Or they’re not confident after listening. …
translation_text.dn8:22.15: Or they don’t demonstrate their confidence. …
translation_text.dn8:22.17: Or they don’t succeed in their practice.’
translation_text.dn8:22.19: What should be said is this: ‘The ascetic Gotama roars his lion’s roar; he roars it in the assemblies; he roars it boldly; they question him; he answers their questions; his answers are satisfactory; they think him worth listening to; they’re confident after listening; they demonstrate their confidence; they practice accordingly; and they succeed in their practice.’
translation_text.dn8:23.0: 7. The Probation For One Previously Ordained
translation_text.dn8:23.1: Kassapa, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
translation_text.dn8:23.2: There a certain fervent celibate named Nigrodha asked me about the higher disgust of sin.
translation_text.dn8:23.4: He was extremely happy with my answer.”
translation_text.dn8:23.5: “Sir, who wouldn’t be extremely happy after hearing the Buddha’s teaching?
translation_text.dn8:23.6: For I too am extremely happy after hearing the Buddha’s teaching!
translation_text.dn8:23.8: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, so too the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn8:23.9: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn8:23.10: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
translation_text.dn8:24.1: “Kassapa, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
translation_text.dn8:24.2: However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”
translation_text.dn8:24.3: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”
translation_text.dn8:24.4: And the naked ascetic Kassapa received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.dn8:24.5: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Kassapa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn8:24.6: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.dn8:24.7: And Venerable Kassapa became one of the perfected.
